awd_titl_txt: Theory-Driven Solutions to Robust and Non-Convex Data Science Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many solutions to data science problems are based on non-convex optimization. Recent surprising theoretical and empirical results have shown that directly solving non-convex problems can yield computationally efficient, high-accuracy algorithms.  This has spurred the expanding body of work on the analysis of non-convex algorithms for a variety of structured data problems. One class of these is robust recovery problems, which aim to recover a hidden structure in corrupted data. While robustness is a classical theme in mathematical statistics, computationally efficient methods with guaranteed accuracy for high levels of corruption have not been widely studied. Non-convex minimization methods indicate the potential to obtain competitive speed and accuracy for such problems, as was already demonstrated by the PI and his collaborators on the problem of robust subspace recovery. The research work aims to further establish and extend such guarantees to many other robust recovery problems whose solutions are crucial for modern applied problems. Applications include the problem of three-dimensional reconstruction from a set of two-dimensional images.
 
The PI and his collaborators aim to develop robust theory and algorithms for truly challenging non-convex recovery problems. These recovery problems are typically NP-hard with highly complex energy landscapes. However, these landscapes often exhibit special structure that seems to allow for recovery under certain adversarial settings and recovery with high probability under certain generative models. For some of the problems of outlier-robust optimization over special, continuous non-convex sets, the PI and his collaborators aim to establish that the corresponding non-convex energy landscapes are "well-tempered" under some generic conditions. This implies that, under these conditions, one may apply an iterative scheme initialized at a pre-specified point and guarantee its fast convergence to the global minimum of the energy landscape. In other challenging discrete settings, "multi-valley" landscapes are observed. In this case, special structures and phase transitions will be quantified. The PI and his collaborators plan to apply their  theory-driven, non-convex optimization solutions in order to solve several applied scientific problems, in particular, problems that arise in the current pipeline of structure from motion in computer vision.

por.por_cntn:
The project advanced the study of robust recovery problems in data science. By robust, we mean that the developed methods were not too sensitive to corruptions in a data set. The basic motivation behind the development of robust procedures is that real data often do not subscribe to the clean assumptions required by many classical statistical procedures. Robust recovery problems aim to recover a hidden structure in a data set in the presence of large corruption. Such problems are very natural in many applications that deal with highly corrupted data. Their mathematical study allows better understanding of these problems and can eventually suggest better algorithms to handle these problems, which are guaranteed to perform well. While robustness is a classical theme in mathematical statistics, computationally efficient methods with guaranteed accuracy for high levels of corruption have not been widely studied. 

The PI and his collaborators worked on a broad spectrum of robust recovery problems. One problem is that of robust subspace recovery. In this problem one wishes to reduce the dimension of a high-dimensional and corrupted data, so it is simpler to describe or visualize it, while being robust to corruption. The PI and his collaborators proposed a new mathematical theory and algorithms for a well-known non-convex formulation for this problem. This theory showed that despite the non-convex problem, it behaves nicely in a local region and it is easy to compute an initial point in this local region and then converge fast to the optimal solution in this region. This was a very surprising result that provided a theoretically-guaranteed fast solution to robust subspace recovery. Similarly, the PI and his collaborators established theoretical guarantees for a computationally efficient solution to the very basic and needed problem of robust covariance estimation in high-dimensions.

There are many robust recovery problems in computer vision that require more rigorous attention. Many of these problems fall under the setting of group synchronization. In this setting there are objects, such as cameras, with associated states, such as locations or orientations. The main problem is estimating the states of objects from the relative state measurements between pairs of objects. For example, recovering orientations of cameras from highly corrupted measurements of their relative orientations. The PI and his collaborators developed theoretically-guaranteed procedures to solve some of these problems. 

The general theory developed to guarantee the performance of the proposed algorithms and understand the mathematical foundations of the studied areas is also of independent interest. It contributes to the mathematical study of difficult optimization problems with highly corrupted data. It also helps clarify complex energy landscapes of such problems. For example, the PI and his collaborators establish the well-temperedness of the energy landscape for a common setting of robust subspace recovery under some generic conditions. In another challenging discrete setting, the PI and his collaborators quantified phase transitions of recovery. Theory was also developed for a novel message passing algorithm. Unlike previous message passing algorithms, the theoretical guarantees of this particular algorithm do not require strong assumptions. The PI expects that similar algorithms that will be developed in the future will enjoy the same property. 

The theoretically-guaranteed solutions were applied to solve several applied scientific problems and had a clear broader impact beyond the area of mathematics. For example, the very recent message-passing least squares algorithm developed by the PI and his collaborators is already referred to in follow up papers in computer vision as a state-of-the-art algorithm. A patent on corruption detection for digital three-dimensional environment reconstruction was recently issued and it indicates the potential for successful commercial applications. Since the project addressed a large and diverse community, the PI and his collaborators made any product resulting from this project available online. 

The PI guided graduate and undergraduate students in research and worked with a diverse group of students. The most significant and non-standard educational activities of the PI aimed to prepare students for successful careers in industry. For this purpose, the PI organized the industrial problems seminar, where leading researchers from industry discussed their research problems and their transition from an academic environment to leadership in industry, and met with students (either in person or virtually). The PI also co-organized the IMA data science seminar. Attending these seminars and meeting with the speakers helped students prepare themselves for industry. The talks and their materials are available online to the wider community (during the pandemic some of the talks were virtually attended by more than 100 participants). The PI also helped organize industrial internships for undergraduate and graduate students and updated resources for internships online. 

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
